creditline: The Christina N. and Swan J. Turnblad Memorial Fund
description: large reproduction of black and white image of Native Americans dancing, wearing feathered headdresses, beadwork garments and leggings and knee bands with bells; white text in sky: "Protect us by Thy might"; white text at bottom of image: "INDIAN WAR DANCE A 381 (circled) / RISE PHOTO RAPID CITY S.D."; quillwork American flag affixed at bottom center of photo above caption; text written in black ink in cursive in bottom margin: "Native American send proportionally more of their people off to war more than any other group in America."
medium: Archival digital print, pigments, and quillwork
object_name: Print with hand-writtent text and collaged elements
text:
In each panel of "Dear America", Tom Jones appropriates and enlarges historic images of Native Americans from postcards, then uses verses of the patriotic song "America" (1832) to unpack the experience and often unwritten history of Native Americans in the United States. Jones carefully selected each photograph to blend portraits and additional images together. The lyrics offer commentary and invite us to consider the
contradictions and struggles that Native Americans face. Added to these photograph montages are bead and quillwork, providing additional layers of Native American artistic traditions that hold thousands of years of meaning and context
title: Dear America: Protect Us By Thy Might
